results.title: Why Eros?
results.brief_description: The Shaftesbury Society has a number of schools and hostels in Britain to look after mainly physically handicapped people. The film concentrates on children with muscular dystrophy and spina bifida and shows them at various activities.

results.title: Why drown?
results.brief_description: Demonstrates “drown-proofing” developed by Fred Lanoue by showing how to survive for long periods in water in an emergency. Shows how to discard and use clothing, time breathing and reduce fatigue in detail. Features Lloyd Bridges and Murray Rose.

results.title: Why'd the beetle cross the road?
results.brief_description: In answer to the question which has puzzled sages throughout the centuries, this short whimsical film gives us a bug’s eye view of the meaning of life. It stars a determined beetle who slowly makes his way across an ocean-side bikepath, humming a medley of familiar tunes while he evades or surmounts a series of obstacles.

results.title: Whose neighbourhood is this?
results.creator_credit: Richard Gebhardt and Mitchell Gebhardt Film Co
results.brief_description: Deals with the problem of serious crime, including interviews with victims of robbery and assault, police, and criminals. Gives advice on locks and security. The film is aimed at a general audience, and takes a “common man” approach.

results.title: Who Killed Target 1967?
results.brief_description: A vengeful female scientist, outraged by Godard’s victimisation of Anna Karina, constructs a beautiful female robot to seduce and destroy lovers attracted solely by physical beauty.

results.title: Who cares about Jamie?
results.brief_description: Discusses the problem of metal health and suggests prevention as a solution. Follows James through a few hours of his young life and then analyses the reaction of adults involved. Stresses the role adults, particularly partner and teachers play: a child needs understanding at every stage of development if he is to acquire the capacity to face life.

results.title: Who's responsible?
results.creator_credit: Robert Sande and JW Newman Corp
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Guidance for the 70’s”.
I am the cause of my own effects. This is a difficult concept for many to accept; most people prefer to “blame” others or environment for what happens to them. Teenagers attending a PACE conference deal with the concept of responsibility. Their discussions highlight how ‘what happens to you is under your own control to a very great extent’ and that, by exercising your choice, you can ‘create the effect your want to have in your life’.

results.title: Putting yourself together
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Guidance for the 70’s”.
Two teenagers and counsellor Daniel Whiteside take a close look at how to think your way past the put-downs or problems that often weaken your self-image. The give-and-take between the three, draws us into the film and challenges us all to start taking control of this part of our lives.
